results.title: The Last temptation of Christ [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Barbara de Fina, Cineplex Odeon and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: A controversial and challenging film of Jesus Christ’s life. Based on the novel by Nikos Kazantzakis, this Christ is an anguished, vain, sensual man battling the forces of both good and evil. The film traces the conflicts that lead to his final disavowal of the flesh in favour of the life of the son of God. Scorsese had for years tried to film the Kazantzakis’ novel and on its release it was met with great debate and fury. The film, however, is deeply spiritual. With Willem Dafoe as Jesus, Barbara Hershey as Mary Magdalene, Harvey Keitel as Judas, and an impressive cameo by David Bowie as Pontius Pilate. Music by Peter Gabriel.

results.title: La Bamba
results.creator_credit: Luis Valdez, Taylor Hackford, New Visions Pictures and Columbia
results.brief_description: Musical biography of Ritchie Valens, a poor Mexican-American who became a rock’n’roll sensation at age 17 in the 1950’s. Lou Diamond Phillips portrays Valens whose musical career ended when he was killed in the plane crash that also claimed the life of Buddy Holly. The music of Valens is performed by Los Lobos on the soundtrack.

results.title: Jericho
results.creator_credit: Thornton Freeland, Walter Futter and Buckingham
results.brief_description: In France 1917, heroic corporal Jericho Jackson accidently kills his abusive seargent. He is charged with the murder but escapes from military prison leaving his friend Captain Mack behind to face a five year prison sentence after being accused of assisting his escape. When Captain Mack is released in 1922, he vows to track down and capture Jericho who has by this time has made a home for himself in North Africa, practicing medicine and uniting the disparate Arab tribes on the annual salt caravan. When Mack finally confronts Jericho, has difficulty destroying the life he has built. Stars Paul Robeson, Henry Wilcoxon, Wallace Ford, John Laurie, Princess Kouka. Paul Robeson sings several songs including ‘Brother are you going my way?’.

results.title: Paperback hero
results.creator_credit: Antony J. Bowman, John Winter, Lance Reynolds, Paperback Films, State of Queensland and AFFC
results.brief_description: Longtime friends Jack and Ruby are about to share a big secret when publicist Ziggy arrives in their one horse town to find the newly successful romance writer, Ruby Vale. Trukkie Jack (Hugh Jackman), eager to keep his new vocation and the autobiographical elements of the two lead characters a secret, manages to convince Ruby to go along with the charade, provided that the publishing company foots the bill for Ruby’s much anticipate wedding to Hamish. Alone and away from home, Ruby and Jack are forced to question what they’re passionate about and whether they have the courage to resist the stereotypes surrounding them and stand up for it. Cast also includes Andrew S. Gibert, Jeanie Drynan and Bruce Venables. Music score by Oscar nominated Burkhard Dallwitz (“The Truman show”).

results.title: Wing Chun
results.brief_description: Inspired by an historical figure, “Wing Chun” is a martial arts film with an unusual feminist sway. It is 19th Century China, and a group of bandits attacks a remote Chinese village in an attempt to kidnap a beautiful young widow, Charmy. Their plans are disrupted, however, by Yim Wing Chun, a local bean-curd shop owner who also happens to be a master fighter. She defeats the bandits single-handedly, thus infuriating their leader who comes back to the town with a vengeance. The plot thickens with the return of Wing Chun’s childhood sweetheart, now also a martial arts master, who returns after a very long absence. He soon falls for Charmy, mistaking her for Wing Chun while at the same time taking Wing Chun for a man. What ensues are some comical manoeuvring and astounding fight sequences which culminate in the final showdown between Wing Chun and the bandits. Cast includes: Michelle Yeoh, Donnie Yen and Tsui Siu Keung. In Cantonese with English subtitles.

results.title: Bedrooms and hallways [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Rose Troche, Dorothy Berwin, Ceci Dempsey and Berwin and Dempsey Productions
results.brief_description: Rose Troche’s (“Go Fish”) second feature film is a gentle and amusing study into the nuances of sexual preference, dating and masculinity. Using Leo’s (Kevin McKidd) 30th birthday bash as a basis, the film traces Leo’s relationship to the guests; gay room mate Darren (Tom Hollander) and his real estate agent boyfriend (Hugo Weaving) with a penchant for using the bedrooms of the houses he’s selling for their trysts; straight and single friend Angie (Julie Graham); new Age guru and leader of Leo’s men’s group, Keith (Simon Callow); Leo’s previous boyfriend, Brendan (James Purefoy) and Brendan’s current girlfriend, Sally (Jennifer Ehle), who also happens to be Leo’s high school sweetheart. Central to the film are the gatherings of the men’s group for masculine assertiveness and when Leo admits his attraction to seemingly straight, Irishman Brendan, it opens the floodgates for other members of the group with surprising results. (Awards: Winner Audience Award, London Film Festival, 1998)

results.title: Summer of Sam
results.creator_credit: Spike Lee, Jon Kilik, 40 Acres and a Mule Filmworks and Touchstone
results.brief_description: Set in New York City in the summer of 1977, “Summer of Sam” examines the effects of a massive heatwave on the city as well as the paranoia and fear created by the random serial murders committed by a psychopath who only signed himself, Son of Sam. But though the serial killer plot sets the film in motion, “Summer of Sam” is about much much more, for it is in 1977 when the emerging anarchism of the punk movement collided with the hedonism of the disco era. The hunt for the Son of Sam is merged with the story of two couples: Vinny (John Leguizamo) and Diona (Mira Sorvino), a married Italo-American couple whose relationship is threatened by Vinny’s guilt-stricken affairs; and Ritchie (Aidrien Brody) and Gloria (Jennifer Esposito), two outcasts - he because he refuses to fit the macho stereotypes of the Italian culture, she because of her “slutty” past - who both find acceptance in the growing punk scene of downtown New York. By focussing his camera on the world of working-class Italo-Americans, Spike Lee is not abandoning his commitment to examining American racism. Instead, by accurately representing a segment of the white world in a specific historic and cultural moment, Lee reveals the underlying racism, misogyny and narrow-mindedness of American mass culture. Being a Spike Lee joint, the film is also a wonderful celebration of music, both disco and punk, as well as a sophisticated examination of love and marriage, and bisexuality. Fast-paced, with excellent art design and a superb score, “Summer of Sam” emerges as a bittersweet love poem to the city of New York: its clubs and its porn theatres, its residents black and white, its uptown charms and its downtown sleaze. A contender for the most underrated film of recent times.

results.title: Kikujiro
results.creator_credit: Takeshi Kitano, Takio Yoshida, Masayuki Mori, Nippon Herald Films, Bandai Visual Company and Office Kitano
results.brief_description: Kikujiro, a lazy small time gangster, agrees to take a lonely boy who lives with his grandmother on a road trip during the summer holidays. The two set off to find the boy’s mother who he has never met. Over the course of the return journey the pair meet up with a range of eccentric characters who engage in a series of absurd games and exchanges. While Kitano’s deadpan comic character with a tendency to extreme and sudden violence is familiar from his earlier work, ‘Kikujiro’ marks a departure from the milieu of the criminal underworld to focus on the unlikely bond that gradually develops between the man and boy. The film evokes Chaplin’s ‘The Kid’, both in Kitano’s trademark use of visual gags and in its sentimental bittersweet tone. In Japanese with English subtitles. Cast includes Takeshi Kitano, Yusuke Sekiguchi and Kayoko Kishimoto.

results.title: The Love letter
results.creator_credit: Peter Ho-sun Chan, Kate Capshaw, Midge Sanford, Sarah Pillsbury and NBCUniversal
results.brief_description: The lives of residents of Loblolly by the Sea are transformed by the discovery of a passionate love letter, written to and from a nameless person. Divorcee Helen McFarquar (Kate Capshaw), first to read the letter begins a steamy romance with the much younger Johnny (Tom Everett Scott) who helps out in the bookstore where she works. The awakening of dormant feelings questions her to re-assess her relationship to George (Tom Selleck), an old friend from the past who has always been in love with her but lacks the eloquence and poetry of the letter. As the letter changes hands to Helen’s friend and co worker (Ellen DeGeneres), the local policeman, it alters their lives and those around them indelibly, and as Helen’s distant mother arrives back to Loblolly from overseas she discovers they have more in common than she realised. Cast also includes Blythe Danner and Geraldine McEwan. Based upon the novel by Cathleen Schine.

results.title: The Flight of dragons
results.creator_credit: Jules Bass, Arthur Rankin Jnr and Rankin-Bass Productions
results.brief_description: Journey back to a magical time when the skies were filled with dragons in this feature-length animated version of Peter Dickinson’s acclaimed book. The tale is of the sinister Red Wizard Ommadon (James Earl Jones), who threatens to destroy nature. The world’s only hope is a man of science and magic from the future named Peter (John Ritter), snatched from the 20th century by the Green Wizard Carolinus (Harry Morgan) to capture Ommadon’s Red crown and thus take away his powers. Peter, accompanied by a fire-breathing dragon, an outlaw elf and a noble knight, applies modern-day logic to battling ancient evil.
